ResponseText: There is a distinction between patriotism and nationalism - which I think you've tended to obscure in your reference to Nazi Germany by comparison with Britain. Patriotism is a sentiment of attachment - i.e. love of one's country; while nationalism is associated with an ideology of national superiority. Another contrast is between a respect for political institutions and laws (patriotism), and a belligerent devotion to race, language, and custom (nationalism). Doesn't any vilification arise from confusing the difference between between patriot and nationalist? To answer this question, you might need to ask another: would you be prepared to fight and even die in defence of your country? An affirmative answer might go some way towards defining what patriotism is. James.

A patriot is someone who wants the best for their country. A nationalist is someone who wants the best for their country, and believes that to achieve this requires doing harm to other peoples' countries. If you do not see a distinction between the two, then it would seem you agree with the nationalists, that the way for one nation to prosper is to harm others, eg by going to war for resources, by blocking their exports from entering your country. The classical liberals were certainly patriots, but they believed that the road to prosperity was built on peace and trade with other nations. Their opponents were the nationalists. Nationalism prospers precisely because of this false belief, that to prosper you must do harm, and though you may consider yourself anti-nationalist, if you propagate this falsity, you will fuel nationalism. There is nothing wrong with patriotism, there is plenty wrong with nationalism, because it is built on a false premise.
